_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC.

Risk Management Plan: Executive Summary



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, has a commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the processes. The company policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS

The Worst Case Scenario (WCS) associated with a release of a regulated flammable substance at the refinery is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) involving the catastrophic failure of LPG Bullet Tank T-900-1.  The assumed LPG mixture consists of 40% propane, 40% butane, and 20% isobutane.  The maximum distance to the 1-psi endpoint for this tank is 0.4 miles from the storage site. No credit for passive mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this WCS. Note that the relief valves for this tank is piped to the plant emergency flare. The flare will act as a safety device in the event of an unanticipated release. 



The first  Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) for regulated flammable substances at the refinery is a release due to a faulty transfer hose connection at the LPG loading rack which results in a butane release of 2,500 lb/min for 30 minutes for a total of 75,000 lbs released. The maximum distance to the 1-psi endpoint for this alternative scenario with a successive explosion would be 0.2 miles from the source. The second ARS for regulated flammable substances at the refinery is a fire in the Crude Unit where responders are not able to control the fire before a BLEVE occurs resulting in 10,506 lb of butane from the V-502 LRS Hot Drum is consumed in a fire ball. The maximum distance to the 1-psi

endpoint for this alternative scenario with a successive explosion would be 0.1 miles from the source.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS



Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC has processes subject to the Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA) Process safety Management (PSM) regulation 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP).  The plant adheres to all applicable federal and state regulatory statutes.  The plant has established programs based on OSHA PSM to evaluate and identify potential risk through management of change programs, mechanical integrity program and process hazard assessments.  Actions to minimize potential releases are facilitated by having trained personnel who participate in the programs; the use of qualified contractors and by utilizing documented operating procedures, pre-start-up safety reviews, established safe work practices. Incidents are investigated and compliance audits performed to periodically assess the programs. 



The processes at Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. Collectively, accident prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors. In addition to the accident prevention program activities, process safety features exist on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



Release Detection



HC detectors with alarms within the Crude Unit, Solvents Unit and ULSD Units. Hydrogen Sulfide detectors are within the ULSD Units. All these alarm in the control room and locally.



Release Containment/Control



Containment and/or control measures include process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases

, valves to permit isolation of the process, the curtailment via diking to contain liquid releases, and redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., independent firewater system). 



Release Mitigation

Fire suppression and extinguishing systems. On-site fire truck and foam cannon. Trained and certified hazard materials emergency response and industrial firefighting personnel. Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus) Fire suppression and extinguishing systems are automatic and manual type in the truck loading and unloading and the LPG areas.



Additionally, Calumet maintains internal response capabilities with a paid-on-call response team that is trained in industrial firefighting, hazardous materials response and technical rescue. This team is trained in accordance with NFPA and OSHA standards and maintains a presence in the facility 24/7.



Five Year Accident History



Within the past five (5) years Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC has had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts as defined by the Risk Management Program rule (40 CFR 68.10 (b)(1).  The plant has also not experienced during that time period  an incident involving regulated flammables or toxics that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, public evacuations or sheltering in place.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect workers and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of regulated and unregulated substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident c

leanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, has procedures that address maintenance, and inspection of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures annually to learn and practice specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated as needed.

The overall emergency response program for the Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, is coordinated with the Bexar County, Texas, Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, coordinates with local emergency response officials, and local government officials. The refinery has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., on-site emergency responders and firefighters, on-call emergency response personnel and the San Antonio Fire Department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating a quick response to an incident. In addition, Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC, conducts periodic emergency drills and provides annual refresher training to all personnel, as well as training for new employees.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



Calumet San Antonio Refining, LLC conducts ongoing efforts to reduce risk through the Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management.  These include recommendations from process hazard assessments, employee suggestions, incident investigations, compliance audits and a review of preventative maintenance and mechanical integrity programs.
